newsitem.title: BELGIUM: CAMPINE SAYS DIVERSIFIED ITS PORTFOLIO.
newsitem.headline: CAMPINE SAYS DIVERSIFIED ITS PORTFOLIO.

text.p: Belgian battery recycling company Campine NV said on Friday it had "renewed" its portfolio in 1996, pulling out of two investments in the U.S. and India, but buying into other ventures.

In a statement issued a week after it sounded a profit warning, Campine said it had disolved its U.S. Campine America LLC joint venture, for a charge of 12 million francs in its 1996 accounts, and also sold its "non-strategic" 40 percent minority stake in Indian Uni Campine. Financial details were not given.

New acquisitions included a 50 percent stake in a Nickel Cadmium (NiCad) battery recycling venture and the foundation at the beginning of 1997 of a 100 percent-owned U.S. company to distribute antimony oxides.
Campine said it had also taken a 51-percent stake in a Belgian company F-Stop NV which would start marketing a fireproofing material for wood and paper products "in the coming months."
Further investments in fireproofing businesses were envisaged, the company said.
